text:
SPEAKER 1: Can we continue that
discussion about India's poor

and the role of business
in helping that situation,
helping the poverty?

I read recently an article
about you commenting

on the issue of
the lack of toilets

for India's rural
population, which

of course is famously
half the population
has no access to toilets.

In that article, you said
something to the effect

that you can build
many, many toilets
and that's not the problem.

The problem is the power
and the water access
to make them usable.

SPEAKER 2: You see, where
it is a big trust now

to set up toilets in
schools because we now

have enough statistical evidence
to know that girls at puberty

drop out of schools
which don't have toilets,
for obvious reasons.
So there is need for it.
So that's one of--

The problem here is
the current technology
for toilets is a wet technology.

It's not a dry technology,
which means the toilet in order
to run needs water.

And in a rural school,
the village council
is probably not supplying water.

If it's not supplying
piped water,

then the school needs
to dig borewell.

To run the borewell,
you need a pump.

To run the pump, you
need electricity,

which is probably not available
24 by 7 of good quality.

So then you need a
diesel generator,

then you need storage
space for the diesel.

So the operating costs
of running the toilets
and the operating complexity.

If you are the headmaster
or principal of that school,

and you want to keep
the toilets running,

you have to become an
expert in diesel pump

maintenance, diesel
generator maintenance,

and then what about borewell
pump maintenance, very

difficult. And remember always,
but generally money even

private philanthropy, but even
government money, all of this

is easier to get
for capital assets.

To build the toilet,
you'll get the money.

The school won't get the
money for the operating costs.

So that's the point
I'm trying to make,

that if we are going to
take this seriously, either

we have to invest in some
radically new technology, which

is dry toilets, which
still is not there.

Might come up in 5 years, but
not at economically affordable.
Prices are still not there.

Or we have to focus,
instead of setting up

1,000 toilets in schools,
we might be better off

setting up 500 toilets
and making sure

that we give them
the operating budget

to have the water and
electricity and to make it run.

That's the point
I'm trying to make.

Building, you know,
it's not a big deal

and we can bring the
cost down dramatically.

Building the toilet
does at least,

and frankly, the way
the end game solution
is also quite easy.
We can have septic tanks.
That's easily done.

It is the water and
availability of continuing water
which is the problem.

SPEAKER 1: So the solution has
to be a political one and not
a business one.

SPEAKER 2: Well
I'm telling, I've

been telling a couple of these
companies which are doing this

as part of their corporate
social responsibility,

saying don't build 1,000,
build 500, and keep the money

the other 500 for
the operating costs.

That's what I'm
trying to tell them.

In fact build 400,
because you have

to put in a bloody
generator and a pump,
and all that costs money.
It's not just a toilet.
Some of them are listening.

So yeah, I think well I think
it's a way of looking at it

and saying are you ticking
off a box in some UN

human development report that
we've set up 1 million toilets,

or do you want
toilets that work?

You know ticking
off these boxes,

it's a silly report
is of no help.
They have to be working.

So then if it's government
doing it, what I've recommended

is we need a citizen's
audit where we go,

they go to each village
school and say yes it's
working, surprise visits.

If you don't do
those things, you

will have a lot of contractors
building toilets and walking

away and making a profit
margin, and then they'll
become derelict ruins.
That's what they will be.
